pt.runtime

Class TaskpoolLIFOWorkFirstGlobal

  • java.lang.Object
    • pt.runtime.AbstractTaskPool
      • pt.runtime.TaskpoolLIFOWorkStealing
        • pt.runtime.TaskpoolLIFOWorkFirstGlobal
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Taskpool

    public class TaskpoolLIFOWorkFirstGlobal
extends TaskpoolLIFOWorkStealing
    Author:
    Weng Hao Work-First - Global Task Population Control. Variation of the WorkStealing task scheduler. While this implementation initially follows the behaviour of the WorkStealing task scheduler, its enqueuing system is restricted by the number of tasks that are enqueued in the system at any given time. The intention of this task enqueuing restriction is to allow the task scheduler to reduce the overall congestion, by forcing workers to temporarily process tasks directly without enqueuing these tasks in the task scheduler. The Global Task Population Control overseas the number of tasks available in the system by using an AtomicInteger as a counter to determine the number of active tasks available in the task scheduler. If this counter exceeds the workFirstUpperThreshold, then the task scheduler will halt all tasks from being enqueued and will force workers to process tasks directly instead. The workFirstLowerThreshold is used to indicate to the task scheduler that it can resume enqueuing again. The AtomicInteger, workFirstCounter, will be updated whenever a task has been enqueued (incremented) or executed/dequeued (decremented).

      • enqueueReadyTask

        protected void enqueueReadyTask(TaskID<?> taskID)
        When enqueuing a task in the WorkStealing policy, if the task is not able to be executed on any arbitrary thread, regardless of the type of enqueuing thread it will be enqueued to the privateQueue of the thread in charge of executing that task. However, if a task can be executed by arbitrary threads, then if the task is a TaskIDGroup it will be enqueued to the globalMultiTask queue, otherwise if the enqueuing thread is a Worker Thread and is not a MultiTaskWorker thread, it will enqueue the task to the head of its local queue. For other cases where the enqueuing thread is a MultiTaskWorker thread or is not a Worker Thread, the task will be enqueued to the tail of a random thread's localQueue.
        Overrides:
        enqueueReadyTask in class TaskpoolLIFOWorkStealing
        Since:
        10/9/2014

      • workerPollNextTask

        public TaskID<?> workerPollNextTask()
        Only worker threads can call this method. This method first checks if the worker thread is a multi-task worker thread. In that case, it will check the thread's privateQueue, and if a task is found, and the attempt for executing it is successful, the task will be passed to the thread to execute.

        However, if the thread's privateQueue is empty, the method searches through the globalMultiTask queue, expands each multi-task into its sub-tasks and enqueues them as ready-to-execute tasks. However, the thread will temporarily return without having anything to execute this time.

        If the worker thread is not a multi-task worker thread, it is first attempted to poll a task from the head of that thread's localOneOffTask queue. If a task is found and the preliminary attempt for executing it is successful, that task will be passed to the thread to execute.

        However, if there are no tasks in the thread's localOneOffTask queue, the thread will try to steal a task from the tail of another thread's localOneOffTask queue. Preferably, if there is a thread from which a task has been stolen already (AKA victim thread), we would like to steal from the same victim's localOneOffTask queue.

        But if there isn't any previous victims for task stealing, starting from a random thread's localOneOffTask queue, we proceed through every thread's localOneOffTask queue (except for the current thread's own queue) and we look for a task to steal from the tail of that local queue. Once a task is found, and the preliminary attempt for executing it is successful, that task will be passed to the thread, and that localOneOffTask queue's corresponding thread will be remembered as the victim thread.

        After all these processes, if there are still no tasks found, the victim thread will be set to null and the method returns null indicating an unsuccessful attempt for polling a task.
        Specified by:
        workerPollNextTask in interface Taskpool
        Overrides:
        workerPollNextTask in class TaskpoolLIFOWorkStealing
        Returns:
        Since:
        14/9/2014

      • setThreshold

        public static void setThreshold(int threshold)
        Assigns the threshold value that is used to determine the number of tasks to be enqueued, before Work-First is enforced. In TaskpoolLIFOWorkFirstGlobal, the setThreshold() and getThreshold() refers to the number of allowable tasks that can be enqueued in the task scheduler before it enforces Work-First on the system and directly processes the next task. The default value for the upperBoundThreshold is 70.
        Parameters:
        threshold -

      • getThreshold

        public static int getThreshold()
        Returns the current threshold value set for the given task scheduler. In TaskpoolLIFOWorkFirstGlobal, the getThreshold() refers to the number of allowable tasks that the task scheduler can enqueue before Work-First is enforced on the system.
        Returns:

      • setLowerBoundThreshold

        public static void setLowerBoundThreshold(int threshold)
        Assigns the lower bound threshold value for the Global Task Population Control. This value is used to determine when it is possible for the task scheduler to resume enqueuing, when Work-First is currently enforced on the system. The default value for the lowerBoundThreshold is 10.
        Parameters:
        threshold -

      • getLowerBoundThreshold

        public static int getLowerBoundThreshold()
        Returns the value of the current lower bound threshold (lowerBoundThreshold) for the Global Task Population Control.
        Returns:
